Speaker: teenage boy
Dialogue: Did you hear that?

Speaker: fat knight
Dialogue: Hear what? The wolf HOWLS AGAIN. The Boy shivers, fearful.

Speaker: teenage boy
Dialogue: The innkeeper told me --

Speaker: fat knight
Dialogue: I know what he told you. He told you about the Wolf. The Beast of Villiers la Croise.  The people of that village have been spreading that nonsense since before you were a tickle in your daddy's prick. I'd give you a whipping for believing it if I thought it would do any good. The Old Knight stares into the fire, then speaks.

Speaker: old knight
Dialogue: I used to travel these woods. They told the same stories then that they do now. Only I heard them from a man who actually saw the beast with his own eyes.

Speaker: fat knight
Dialogue: Half the people in these parts claim to have seen it.

Speaker: old knight
Dialogue: This man claimed it was the last thing he ever saw. The Wolf took his eyes. And half his face.  I saw his scars and empty eye sockets. His skin looked like it was on inside-out. It didn't seem to me like the kind of thing a man would make up a story about. He shrugs. His companions exchange an unnerved look.

Speaker: fat knight
Dialogue: What the devil are you --?!

Speaker: teenage boy
Dialogue: Wait, wait! Be quiet! He raises a hand. He's heard something. They listen. FOOTSTEPS. Approaching through the mud. The Boy's hand clutches a dagger, but the Fat Knight reaches out and stays him, terrified. The Boy follows his look. We never get a good look at THE FIGURE walking toward them. But what the men see scares them shitless. It stops near the cart. The men huddle together, watching as it slowly starts to walk around the cart -- -- then suddenly jumps atop it. The Figure is now above them. With each step it takes, the boards of the wooden cart CREAK and bend under its weight. A long beat. Then the Figure jumps down again, landing behind the men, startling them. It pauses. The men cower, shivering... Suddenly, the cart is flipped over as if it weighed nothing, revealing the terrified Knights beneath it. Lightning FLASHES. A shadow falls over them. The men scramble to their feet, but the Old Knight slips in the mud. The Boy stops to help him, but then the Old Knight starts screaming, something GROWLS, and the Boy stops short at what he sees. The Fat Knight runs.

Speaker: teenage boy
Dialogue: Wait! We have to help him! The Fat Knight ignores him. The Old Knight shrieks. We hear the same TEARING and POPPING that this thing made while eating the horse. The Boy quickly looks around... ... sees a curved Arabian scimitar lying in the mud, fallen from the overturned wagon. He grabs it and as the Fat Knight runs, the Boy stands his ground. He hefts the blade. He's young, but he has used this before. A lot. Rain beats down on his face and lightning FLASHES as he confronts the thing that is devouring the Old Knight.

Speaker: lucie
Dialogue: Honestly, Isabelle. Just kill it.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I can't. It's the fifth commandment. Thou shalt not kill. Lucie rolls her eyes. Isabelle crouches, letting the spider crawl off her hand. She watches it skitter away, then calls to Suzette, feigning nonchalance:

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I'm going to take Father some water.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: All right. Don't be long. Isabelle smiles, grabs a bucket and ladle, and anxiously heads toward the village. Lucie watches her go, dubious.

Speaker: carpenter
Dialogue: Hey, there! Let one of these young lads get that for you.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I can do it myself. The Carpenter smiles. Of course she can.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Mother thought you might be thirsty.

Speaker: cesaire
Dialogue: That was very thoughtful of her. He gives her a knowing look as he ladles a drink from the bucket. Isabelle's gaze drifts from him to another woodcutter, working off by himself. His name is PETER . He makes eye contact with Isabelle for a moment, then wipes his brow and calls out to the WOODCUTTER BOSS.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: I'm taking a break.

Speaker: woodcutter boss
Dialogue: A break? Does that mean you're going to start working? The other Woodcutters LAUGH. Peter walks away. Isabelle's gaze lingers on him too long. Cesaire notices, not entirely comfortable with what he sees...

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: I was afraid you weren't coming.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: You should know better than that.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I think my sister's starting to suspect something.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Do you think she'll tell your father?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I don't care. I wish she would tell him. I want everyone to know. Besides, my father likes you.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Of course he does. Right up until the point where he figures out what I'm doing with his daughter. Peter glances back and Isabelle follows his look. Through the trees, she sees her father and the group of grim Woodcutters, still in serious conversation.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: What's going on?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: You haven't heard?  Three men. They found them this morning just off the Center Road. At least they think it was three men. There wasn't enough left to piece them back together. A long beat as Isabelle takes this in. Then:

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Was it the Wolf?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Could it have been anything else? Isabelle shudders. No, it couldn't have been.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: We should have killed that monster a long time ago.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I know. You say that every month.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I'd better go.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Same time tomorrow?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Don't get used to this. I start my sewing lessons next week.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: You really think you can go all day without seeing me?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I'll manage somehow. Pride is a cardinal sin, by the way.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: I can think of worse sins I could be committing. She gives a cautioning look, then leaves with a smile.

Speaker: herald
Dialogue: Half full! Half full!

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: You mind your grandmother, understand? You're her student now, the same as the other girls.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Yes, Mother. Suzette hands her the basket with a proud look.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: My last baby has grown up.

Speaker: lucrece
Dialogue: You're only encouraging him.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I know. THREE GIRLS . A playful PUPPY tags along. Prudence and Rosemaria look tired, but Roxanne greets Isabelle with a big smile.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: You look happy.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Aren't you excited?

Speaker: prudence
Dialogue: It's too early to be excited.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: I'm just trying to look on the bright side.

Speaker: rosemaria
Dialogue: Well, stop it before somebody hurts you. The girls have a laugh at Roxanne's expense.

Speaker: prudence
Dialogue: Did you hear about her and the Darley brothers?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Oh, no! Which one?

Speaker: prudence
Dialogue: Both! On the same night! Isabelle gives an incredulous look and Prudence tries to contain her laughter. Rosemaria hears and looks back at them. She scowls at Isabelle.

Speaker: rosemaria
Dialogue: Why does your grandmother have to live so far away?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: What's the matter, Rosemaria? Having trouble walking? Prudence laughs. Roxanne frowns, disapproving. Rosemaria shoots Isabelle a dirty look.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Well, stop dawdling. Come on, come on. The girls hurry inside, but Grandmother stops Isabelle.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Your mother has warned you not to expect any special treatment from me?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Yes, ma'am. Grandmother eyes her a moment longer, then breaks into a smile and surreptitiously hands her a bright red apple.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Well, then your mother doesn't know me very well, does she? Isabelle smiles as Grandmother ushers her inside.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: There. This is going to be my foundation. Everything I do now will build off of this. She shows the row of stitches to Roxanne.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Roxanne, is this a good foundation?

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Why not?

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Well... you haven't told us what you're making.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: There's something else I haven't told you. I haven't told you why I'm making it. Before you begin any task, you must first always ask yourself why.

Speaker: rosemaria
Dialogue: Why? The girls laugh. Grandmother gives her a patient smile.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Because understanding why you are doing something is the key to doing it successfully. So, before we begin today, let's be certain that we have a good foundation. Who can tell me why you are here?

Speaker: prudence
Dialogue: To become seamstresses. To learn how to sew and mend clothes.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: That's what you are doing. But why are you doing it? Blank looks. None of them have ever considered this.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Isabelle, your sister studied with me last winter. What does she do now?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: She works with the women.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Why don't you work with them?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I don't know how to yet.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: And how does that make you feel? Isabelle thinks for a moment, then has an insight.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Like a child. Grandmother gives her a smile, then continues.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: You will be coming here every day for the next three months. During that time, I will teach you everything you need to know to be productive members of our community. But there is something far more important that will also be happening here. All the girls are paying close attention now, but Grandmother seems to be speaking directly to Isabelle.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: You will be proving your worth and learning your place in the world. And I promise you, when you leave here for the last time, you will never feel like a child again.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: I need to talk to you. Isabelle turns to face him, trying to stay nonchalant.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: What about? Peter just looks at her for a beat. Isabelle turns and sees that the other girls have stopped to watch. Isabelle shoots them a look. The girls take the hint and leave. When they've gone, Peter walks up to Isabelle.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: When were you planning on telling me?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Telling you what?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: That you're engaged to be married to Henri Smith. Isabelle gapes at him, stunned and confused.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Henri Smith? Is this a joke?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Look at me. Just look at me and tell me you didn't know. She looks at him and sees it in his eyes. He's serious.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Who told you this?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Your father. Off Isabelle's look...

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: It's all been arranged. Your marriage to Henri will settle our debt to his father. Isabelle nods, shaken. Cesaire sees that she's upset.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: We know that you and Peter have become friends. But you have adult responsibilities now. That means putting your family's interests ahead of your own.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: So Henri Smith is in the family's interest and Peter is not?

Speaker: cesaire
Dialogue: Peter is a fine young man.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: But what? He's poor? He's an orphan?

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: He's not one of us. His parents were outsiders.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Why? Because they hadn't lived here since Noah built the ark?

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: You mind your tongue. Isabelle is about to respond, when she notices something. Lucie is crying. A beat. Lucie looks up at her parents.

Speaker: lucie
Dialogue: Do you realize how this makes me look? I'm older than her by more than a year. If anyone should be getting married in the spring, it's me. Everyone is taken aback. Lucie storms out of the cottage, angrily wiping tears. Isabelle watches her go.

Speaker: cesaire
Dialogue: This was your idea. Now I have both of them hating me. In the loft, Isabelle and Lucie are in bed... but Isabelle only pretends to be asleep so she can eavesdrop.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: We knew Isabelle was going to be stubborn. It wouldn't be like her to simply do as she's told. She's too much like her grandmother.

Speaker: cesaire
Dialogue: That she is. What about Lucie?

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: She's a good girl, but she's still a child. Talk to her. You're her father. She'll listen to you. Isabelle glances over at Lucie... and sees that she's been eavesdropping, too. Lucie turns away, embarrassed. Isabelle gives her a sad look.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: Hello, Isabelle.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Hello, Henri.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: So I suppose you've heard.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Yes. My parents are very pleased.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: And you? Are you pleased?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: It's a very generous arrangement.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: Do you have any other feelings about it? About me?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I'm not sure. We've never really talked that much.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: I know. That's why I asked you to walk with me. I wanted to talk.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: What for?

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: Well... because we're going to be husband and wife soon.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Not until the spring festival. That's months away. A lot can happen in a few months. Henri seems disappointed. She sees this and reconsiders.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: All right. What would you like to talk about?

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: I'm not really sure. I brought you this. He reaches into his pocket and offers Isabelle a flower. She takes it, suddenly blushing. But just then, she sees Peter walking toward them with another WOODCUTTER.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Well, I'm glad we had this conversation. Isabelle abruptly turns and walks away, leaving Henri surprised and a little hurt. She passes Peter, her eyes averted. He glances back at her as she and walks away...

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: You know, I had a sweetheart when I was your age, too. Isabelle looks up, intrigued in spite of herself. Suzette smiles slyly at her reaction.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: What happened?

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Nothing happened. My parents arranged for me to marry your father and that was the end of that.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Didn't you want to marry your sweetheart?

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Of course, I did. But there's more to marriage than being in love. Love doesn't always last and it certainly doesn't fill your children's bellies in the winter.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: You've never wished you could have married that other boy?

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Not even once. Isabelle eyes her, still uncertain.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: We need to talk.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: You have to go through with it. You have to marry Henri.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I don't care what my parents want. They don't own me. I love you.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: That doesn't matter.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: It does to me. Doesn't it matter to you?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: It's not our decision to make.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: You sound like my mother.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Then maybe you should start listening to your mother.  It's over. They had to find out eventually. Don't turn this into something that it's not. We had our fun, but that's all it ever was. Isabelle looks up at him, shocked and confused.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I don't believe you.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Go home, Isabelle. Go home and grow up. Isabelle gapes at him. Peter walks away.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I don't believe you! He doesn't look back. She watches him go, heartbroken.

Speaker: herald
Dialogue: Full moon! Full moon! Full moon!

Speaker: cesaire
Dialogue: This doesn't concern you, Isabelle.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Yes, Father. Isabelle reluctantly turns and walks away. The girls follow her. Roxanne gives Lucie a concerned look.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: What's wrong with Lucie?

Speaker: rosemaria
Dialogue: How would you feel if you were in love with your sister's fiance? Isabelle stops short and gives Rosemaria a sharp look.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Lucie is not in love with my fiance.

Speaker: rosemaria
Dialogue: Really? So she's just had a crush on him since she was ten?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: As if she would really tell you something like that.

Speaker: rosemaria
Dialogue: She didn't. She told my sister.  Did you honestly not know? Isabelle clearly had no idea, but tries to hide it. Just then, they walk by the blacksmith's shop where Henri works with his father, ADRIEN. Henri smiles at Isabelle.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Come on. We're going to be late. She turns away. Rosemaria gives her a smug look.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Rosemaria...? The other girls stop and hurry back to the fork, dismayed to find Rosemaria headed down the overgrown path.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: What are you doing?

Speaker: rosemaria
Dialogue: What does it look like?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: You can't go that way. You have to stay on the path.

Speaker: rosemaria
Dialogue: This way is faster.

Speaker: prudence
Dialogue: But it's not safe. My brother says the bridge is rotten.

Speaker: rosemaria
Dialogue: I don't care. It's bad enough working all day in that smelly cottage. It's not reasonable for them to expect us to walk that far every day on top of that. She walks away, defiant. The girls look nervous. Then:

Speaker: prudence
Dialogue: If you get lost, nobody will come looking for you. Not tonight. This last part gives Rosemaria pause. She looks down the narrow path. It suddenly seems a little ominous. Grudgingly, she returns to the group. The other girls exchange quiet looks of relief. They continue on. The wind blows leaves across the abandoned path...

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Everyone finish what you're working on. Your parents will be worried if you're not home before it starts to get dark. The girls begin packing up their work. Prudence sighs.

Speaker: prudence
Dialogue: I wish someone would just kill that stupid wolf.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: You can't just kill it. It's not an ordinary wolf. It's a devil- wolf. A servant of Satan himself. Prudence rolls her eyes. Whatever.

Speaker: rosemaria
Dialogue: Who cares what it is? It's only one night a month. You stay inside, lock up the animals, and you don't go into the forest. It's never killed anyone from the village and as long as we leave it alone, it never will.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: My goodness. I had no idea our young people were so woefully uneducated these days.  Our village was not always like this. When I was young, this was a very special place. Traders and merchants came here from lands I'd never heard of selling things I had never seen. King Philip the Bold even visited here once. But that, of course, was before the Wolf came. The girls listen attentively.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Your parents fear the Wolf because they remember when it did kill people from the village. Break down doors in the middle of the night and snatch children right out of their beds. Rumors began to spread that we were cursed. That was when our village began to die. And that was why my husband led a group of men into the woods to kill the Wolf. But instead, it killed him. Isabelle reacts. She has never heard this story before.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: After that, people here didn't have much stomach to go hunting for it anymore. But something had changed. The Wolf stopped killing in the village. Even our livestock were usually safe as long as they were brought inside. So we decided it was safer to compromise. We gave the Wolf its one night a month, the night of the full moon, and it has left us alone ever since.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: People still die.

Speaker: rosemaria
Dialogue: Yes, but nobody we know.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Everyone knows what should be done. But it's not always easy to do what you know is right. Sometimes it's easier to settle for being safe. Isabelle frowns, unsatisfied.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: You were right. About Peter. I was being childish.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: You'll do as you're told. It's all been arranged.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: The family gains the same no matter which one of us marries him. And I don't love Henri. Lucie does. Lucie looks up, surprised to be dragged into this.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: She's right. It's not fair. I will gladly trade places with her. A beat. Then, without looking up, Lucie whispers:

Speaker: lucie
Dialogue: Shut up. Isabelle is stung, the smile wiped from her face.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I'm sorry... I...

Speaker: lucie
Dialogue: Please. Just shut up and mind your own business. A tense beat. Isabelle looks away, hurt and confused.

Speaker: boy
Dialogue: I'm the Wolf! I'm going to eat you up!

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: What on earth --? The Young Man glances at Isabelle. Something about the look in his eyes makes Isabelle go pale...

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: It's my little secret. A pinch will help you rest. A little more and you'll sleep through the end of the world. Grandmother smiles. Isabelle smiles back, weak.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I think I'd like that.

Speaker: merchant
Dialogue: She had it coming, if you ask me. What the hell was she doing out there? Then they notice that Isabelle is right behind them, drawing a water from the well. Both men shift uncomfortably, but she pretends she didn't hear.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: What is it?

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Nothing. Grandmother curtly wraps what she's found in a washcloth.

Speaker: father auguste
Dialogue: Wherefore each man and woman that is wise, make him ready thereto; for we all shall die, and we know not how soon...

Speaker: marguerite
Dialogue: Take your brother home. Embarrassed, Roxanne quickly grabs Claude and drags him away, but he fights her, crying and kicking. Isabelle's family is met by Henri and his father, Adrien.

Speaker: adrien
Dialogue: She was a good girl. We all loved her. He's looking at Cesaire and shakes his hand, but he briefly glances at Suzette. Isabelle notices the look, but then she spots Peter leaving the church. She makes brief eye contact with him before Henri interrupts.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: I'm here for you, too. But her gaze follows Peter as he walks away...

Speaker: cesaire
Dialogue: A line has been crossed. The beast must be destroyed!

Speaker: merchant
Dialogue: Your daughter crossed the line. She went into the woods.

Speaker: cesaire
Dialogue: She was taken. She must have been!

Speaker: merchant
Dialogue: So the Wolf broke into your home and stole your daughter without waking anyone or leaving any sign at all?

Speaker: reeve
Dialogue: It's been almost thirty years since someone here was killed by the Wolf. We've left it alone. Why would it suddenly come and take one of us now? Grandmother gathers her nerve and stands up.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: I know something. Cesaire and Suzette give Grandmother surprised looks. She walks up to the table and hands Attewater the wadded up washcloth we saw her with earlier.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: I found this. I believe it must belong to her attacker. Attewater unfolds the washcloth. There are a few strands of hair inside. He gives her a sharp look.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: This is not animal hair.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: No, it isn't. It's human. A stunned silence comes over the room.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: No man could have done the things that were done to your granddaughter. It must have been the Wolf.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Yet she was holding a man's hair in her hand when she died.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: What are you suggesting?

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: That the man and the Wolf may be one and the same. A low MURMUR works its way through the crowd.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: A werewolf.

Speaker: father auguste
Dialogue: It would explain much. The Pope himself has declared that such creatures exist. The thought gives everyone pause.

Speaker: merchant
Dialogue: Even if you're right, it doesn't help us. The woods are filled with hermits and strangers. If there's a werewolf among them, how will we find it?

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: There are experts in these matters. Men who find and try witches and werewolves. We could request the Church to send someone. Grandmother gives him a sharp look.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Not someone. You're talking about Father Solomon. This sends a ripple of comment through the room.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: He is the Church's most successful werewolf hunter.

Speaker: adrien
Dialogue: But what of his methods? The man once burned down an entire village just to root out one witch.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: Unsubstantiated rumors. The Church has appointed him the Witchfinder General of all Christendom.

Speaker: father auguste
Dialogue: That is also unsubstantiated. Attewater eyes him, but Father Auguste stands his ground.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: I have the utmost confidence in the ability of the Witchfinder General to determine the nature of the beast and put an end to it. I will dispatch a messenger in the morning.

Speaker: cesaire
Dialogue: Even if Father Solomon agrees to help us, it will take weeks for him to get here. That means another full moon. Maybe two. We must defend ourselves. A long, silent beat. Then, Henri stands.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: He's right. The beast broke the peace, not us.

Speaker: reeve
Dialogue: As will I. We all will. Henri is nervous, but tries to appear brave for Isabelle.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Who gave you permission to wear that?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Nobody. I just --

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Your Grandmother made that for Lucie. Take it off. Isabelle hesitates, then does as she's told. Suzette snatches the cloak away from her. A beat.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: It was folded when they found her. Her clothes, too. Did you notice that?

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Someone must have folded them. A beat. Isabelle is reluctant to voice her thoughts...

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: She was so unhappy. Suzette turns, her eyes narrowing dangerously.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: What are you saying?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Maybe she went into the woods on purpose. Maybe she wanted to die. Suddenly: Suzette slaps her across the face. Hard.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Lucie's soul is at peace with God. Don't you ever again suggest otherwise. Suzette turns away in tears. Isabelle is stunned speechless.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Are you all right?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I just need to talk to someone. Can I come in? Peter balks. Just then, a figure appears. Isabelle can't believe her eyes... It's Rosemaria. She's standing behind Peter, but it's clear that she's naked.

Speaker: rosemaria
Dialogue: No. You can't. She wraps an arm around Peter's waist. Isabelle gives him a stricken look and runs away. Peter watches her go.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I hate the cold. Why can't we have lessons in the summer?

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: I suppose that would be easier. But then that would defeat the purpose. People only change when things are difficult. Isabelle gives her a look, understanding, then turns away. Grandmother puts a hand on her shoulder and then leaves her alone. Isabelle stares into the fire...

Speaker: marguerite
Dialogue: I caught the little bastard watching us!

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Watching what? Just then, the Merchant enters from the bedroom, adjusting his clothes. He hesitates when he sees Roxanne, then drops a handful of coins on the table and leaves. Marguerite puts the coins in a leather purse. Roxanne glares at her.

Speaker: marguerite
Dialogue: It's money, isn't it? You could make twice this your first time. They pay more for virgins. Roxanne recoils in disgust and storms out in tears.

Speaker: adrien
Dialogue: Don't do this for Isabelle. She can't marry you if you're dead.

Speaker: adrien
Dialogue: Your mother would be proud to see the man you've become. Henri is moved. He nods, at a loss for words.

Speaker: cesaire
Dialogue: My father died trying to kill the Wolf. For forty years, we have lived in fear of it. But no more. And never again. We don't need a Witchfinder General to rid of us this hell-hated beast. Because by God and all that is holy, the Beast of Villiers la Croise shall die tonight! The men CHEER.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: You're not coming with us?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Are you joking? These fools are as likely to kill each other as they are anything else. Henri shoots him an angry look before moving on. Isabelle and Suzette say goodbye to Cesaire. Isabelle sees Peter through the crowd and quickly looks away. Just then, Henri and Adrien pass by. On impulse, Isabelle runs up and kisses Henri on the mouth. When she's sure that Peter has seen this, she quickly walks away. Henri gives Peter a gloating look. Peter scowls.

Speaker: cesaire
Dialogue: Get that torch out. Henri douses his torch.

Speaker: reeve
Dialogue: Who was that screaming?

Speaker: carpenter
Dialogue: I don't know.

Speaker: merchant
Dialogue: Look. He's gone pale. The others follow his look. There's a LARGE PAW PRINT in the snow. The Men stare at it. Suddenly, the same SCREAM pierces the night, this time coming from deeper in the woods. The Men exchange a wary look, but then start after it.

Speaker: reeve
Dialogue: Which way did it go? The Merchant points a trembling finger. The Reeve plunges into the brush after it and the Men follow.

Speaker: carpenter
Dialogue: The caves. It's in the caves.

Speaker: reeve
Dialogue: Split up. Two groups. Half the Men take one fork, half the other. We follow the Reeve's group down a narrowing passageway. The Men crowd together, hunched low. The SCREAMS seem to be getting louder. The Reeve stops, listening. He turns toward a low crack in the cave wall. The SCREAMS are coming from inside. He shines his torch inside, lowers his head, and walks toward it. The cave

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I heard your father wounded the beast. He was a brave man.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: Did you hear what it did to him? It chewed off his private parts. Isabelle had not heard this. Henri doesn't stop working.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: And I did nothing. I was too scared. I couldn't move. I just let my father be eaten alive. She moves toward him, but he shrugs her away.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: No. I don't want you here. Isabelle gives him a sad look, then leaves. Henri just keeps hammering away on the anvil.

Speaker: lucrece
Dialogue: I thought your mother would be here. They used to be quite close. Isabelle gives her a sharp look, but Lucrece says nothing more. Isabelle looks down at the coffin with a sudden realization...

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: You told me you had a sweetheart before you were married. It was Henri's father, wasn't it?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Lucie was in love with Henri. She could have married him.  Couldn't she have?

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: We arranged for you to marry him.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: But you gained the same no matter which one of us married him. So why did it have to be me?

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: I think you know the answer to that question.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: No. You say it. Suzette's eyes well up. Then:

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Lucie was Henri's half-sister. She was not your father's daughter. Isabelle suddenly looks ill. Reluctant, she asks:

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Am I? Do you even know?

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Yes. I was already pregnant when your father and I married.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Does he know?

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: No. And he must never know. Tears spill down Isabelle's cheeks. She walks away.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: Isabelle!

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: I've found that there's no burden that doesn't at least seem a little lighter on a full stomach.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I don't know what to do. She wants me to pretend like I don't know. How am I supposed to go on living in that house?

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: You have a right to be angry with her. But try not to hate her. Too much hate will eat you alive. Isabelle nods and rests her head on Grandmother's shoulder.

Speaker: cesaire
Dialogue: You're a good girl. Isabelle allows a sad smile, places his hand back on his chest, and leaves.

Speaker: prudence
Dialogue: I heard there's going to be a festival on the night of the next full moon. To celebrate.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: A festival? I've never been to one!

Speaker: prudence
Dialogue: My father says he hasn't seen one since he was a boy.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: It's strange, isn't it? You think because things have been a certain way your whole life that they'll always be the same. Then overnight everything just changes. But Isabelle is distracted. Amidst the morning bustle, she sees Rosemaria laughing with Peter. Roxanne notices. Just then, they hear HORSES approaching. A lot of them. Everyone stops what they're doing, listening, suddenly apprehensive. The girls turn toward the sound and see... ... A DOZEN SOLDIERS in identical armor, silver helmets gleaming in the sun, riding into the square atop armored steeds. The Villagers gape at them in awe. The Soldiers ride escort to a WHITE COACH with a red cross on it, drawn by two horses: one white, one black. A FIGURE rides inside, cloaked in darkness. Isabelle gives it an uneasy look. Leading the Soldiers is the CAPTAIN OF THE GUARD, his helmet adorned with a blood-red plume. He brings the caravan to a halt in front of the Merchant's shop.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: This is Villiers la Croise?

Speaker: merchant
Dialogue: Yes, my lord.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: Summon your bailiff. My master would speak with him at once.

Speaker: merchant
Dialogue: Of course, my lord. May I ask to what does he owe this honor?

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: He requested the services of His Eminence, the Witchfinder General. You may tell him that he has arrived. All eyes turn to the figure in the coach. Only a bejeweled hand is visible, resting on the coach's window.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: This is indeed an honor, Your Eminence. Solomon makes no response. His eyes are on the severed wolf's head on display. Attewater smiles proudly.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: As you can see, our werewolf problem has been dealt with.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: That is no werewolf. Surprise and outrage ripple through the crowd. Isabelle and Roxanne exchange a shocked look.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: When a werewolf dies, it returns to its human form. If what you killed was a werewolf, then you would have a human head skewered atop that pole.

Speaker: reeve
Dialogue: And I suppose you've seen this? A wolf turning into a man?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: My wife's name was Pnlope. She was very pretty. And we were very happy. The Reeve tries to keep the confusion off his face. Attewater and Father Auguste exchange uncertain looks.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: We lived in a village not unlike this place. And not unlike this place, our village was plagued by a werewolf. I went out with some men to hunt it. It never even occurred to me that we might actually find it. But we did. He has everyone's attention now. All eyes are on him.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: It attacked me. All I saw were yellow teeth. I hacked at it with an axe and suddenly it was gone. There was blood on my axe. I had cut off one of its paws. I picked it up and put it in my sack.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Her name was Pnlope. She was very pretty. And we were very happy. Until the day I killed her. Solomon turns and gives Attewater a hard look.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Your werewolf is still alive. And I promise you, it will kill again.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I have examined the body of your blacksmith. There were bruises on his neck from where the beast held him in its jaws, squeezing his throat so that he could not scream.

Speaker: cesaire
Dialogue: But he did scream. We all heard him.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Only when it wanted you to. It used him as bait to lure you into the bit of theater it had prepared.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: Theater? My father is not playacting. He is dead.

Speaker: reeve
Dialogue: And I killed the beast that did it.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: That's what it wants you to think. It did kill your blacksmith. But the animal that you killed was not the werewolf.

Speaker: reeve
Dialogue: There was blood dripping from its teeth.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: The blood was its own. The werewolf most likely wounded it earlier in the evening and left it in the cave for you to find and kill.

Speaker: cesaire
Dialogue: 'Most likely,' he says. Have you ever heard anything more unlikely in your lives?

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: Your Eminence, if what you say is true, that we were somehow fooled by this thing, it could not have done so without foreknowledge of our plan to hunt it.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: That's correct. The werewolf does not live in the forest as you have rather navely assumed. It lives here in the village. Among you. There is a moment of shocked silence. Then mounting anger. Cesaire stands up and gestures to Henri.

Speaker: cesaire
Dialogue: You come here and tell us that this boy's father died for nothing. You accuse us and call us fools. Well, I believe what I can see with my own eyes. That wolf is dead. And I know it's dead because I was with the brave men who killed it.

Speaker: merchant
Dialogue: And what of the festival?

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: The festival was to celebrate the death of the Wolf.

Speaker: merchant
Dialogue: And we say that it's dead! We've spent every full moon for the past forty years cowering in our homes. We've earned a celebration.

Speaker: reeve
Dialogue: And paid for it in blood! Attewater gives Solomon a nervous look. Solomon shrugs.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Have your festival. I will stay on here until then to ensure that you have the celebration you all so richly deserve. The Villagers seem appeased, especially the smug Merchant. A look passes between Solomon and his Captain. Isabelle catches it... and finds it unsettling.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Gloria Patri, et Filio, et Spiritui Sancto. Sicut erat in principio, et nunc, et sempter, et in saecula saeculorum. Amen.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I'm going to the festival.

Speaker: suzette
Dialogue: All right then. She doesn't look up from her knitting. Isabelle leaves.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: I'm sorry...

Speaker: prudence
Dialogue: She acts more like a mother to him than a sister.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Someone has to look after him.

Speaker: prudence
Dialogue: I know. But who looks after her? Isabelle gives Roxanne a sad look.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Take it easy, friend.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: You didn't come with us. The night my father died. Peter's smile fades. Isabelle rushes to pull Henri away.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: You stayed here and let real men do the work you didn't have the belly for.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Please, don't do this -- Henri brushes her aside, but too hard and she stumbles. Peter instantly grabs hold of Henri's wrist. Henri

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Peter! Wait!

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Why? So you can hit me, too?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I just want to make sure you're all right. Peter stops. He whirls on Isabelle, incredulous.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Why can't you just leave me alone?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: You're bleeding.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: So what? What's the matter with you? What do I have to do to make you stop caring about me? Isabelle is taken aback. A beat.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: You think I want to feel like this? You think I enjoy feeling like a fool every day because I can't stop loving you? Peter's bravado falters. He can't completely hide what her words do to him. She looks up at him, realizing...

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Why are you with Rosemaria? You hate Rosemaria.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: I don't have to like her to get what I want from her.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: You're a terrible liar. Isabelle takes a step closer and presses the palm of her hand against his chest. A beat.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: There. You're heart is starting to beat faster. And the little black circles in the middle of your eyes still get bigger when I touch you. She gazes up at him. He tries not to look in her eyes, but can't stop himself.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: You can tell me you don't love me, but I know what you're really feeling. I can feel it with my hand and see it with my eyes. Peter hesitates, then covers her hand with his own.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: I thought being with Rosemaria would be the one thing you would never be able to forgive. I wanted you to hate me.  Isabelle, you are the best thing that could ever happen to me. And I am the worst thing that could ever happen to you.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: How could you think that?

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: I wasn't born here. You and I both know what that means. I will always be a stranger to these people. Your parents will never let us be together.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: That means less to me now than ever. We can leave here. We can go someplace where we'll both be strangers.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: I can't let you do that. You have something here that I will never have. You have a place. You have

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: The only life I want is with you.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Isabelle... I'm wrong for you.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I know you are. I just don't care. She kisses him on the mouth, then quickly steps back, as if she did it before she could change her mind. Then he takes her in his arms and they kiss, long and hard.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I don't want to wait.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: But not like this.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: I can pack the cart tonight and we can leave in the morning.  Is that too soon?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: It's not soon enough. She pulls him to her and kisses him.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: You'd better get back before someone misses you. She gives him a lingering kiss. When she pulls away from him, he sees that she's crying.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: What's wrong?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: This feels like a dream. I'm afraid if I leave you I might wake up. He kisses her and holds her tight. Neither of them notice Henri, angrily watching from the shadows...

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I've never seen it full before... Suddenly -- the CHURCH BELLS start to ring. Everyone falls silent. Confused looks all around. Then, somewhere in the dark... ... a WOLF HOWLS. The Villagers gasp. A WOMAN screams. People start to panic. Claude is knocked down.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Claude! Then something massive pushes its way through the surging crowd, bursting from the darkness... It's THE WOLF. The Villagers gape in horror. It makes the wolf that they killed look like a chihuahua. But there's something about its face that isn't canine at all, but ghoulishly human as it HOWLS at the moon. Suddenly, a group of Villagers throw off their cloaks, revealing themselves to be Solomon's armored Soldiers. Each of them draws a gleaming sword and points it at the Wolf. They've been lying in wait and now they have it surrounded. The Wolf SNARLS at them.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Get to the church, you fools! The Wolf SNARLS up at him. Solomon gives a battle cry:

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Where's Claude? Where is he?!

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Claude! Claude! Roxanne spots Rosemaria and grabs her, begging for help.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Have you seen my brother? Please! But Rosemaria just pushes her aside, panicked. An instant later -- the Wolf appears out of nowhere, jumping on Rosemaria. She screams, then -- CRUNCH. The screams stop. Isabelle and Roxanne gape in horror, then run.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Claude! Where are you?! Isabelle drags her to the ground and covers her mouth.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: You have to stop it. He can't hear you and you are going to get us killed. Do you understand me? Roxanne nods, crying. Isabelle helps her up -- and finds herself face-to-face with the Wolf. Roxanne screams. They run back the way they came, turn another corner --

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Come on! Isabelle climbs the wall, but Roxanne's not going to make it. Isabelle jumps down to help her... ... just as the Wolf's shadow falls over the alley. The girls watch helplessly as the Wolf slowly walks toward them, SNARLING and glaring at them with its strange, near- human eyes. Then, inexplicably... the Wolf speaks.

Speaker: the wolf
Dialogue: Well, well. You look very pretty this evening, my dear. Good enough to eat. The Wolf's voice is sonorous, seductive. The Devil's voice. Isabelle stammers, unable to believe her senses.

Speaker: the wolf
Dialogue: It's considered polite to thank someone when they pay you a compliment. Are you being impolite, Isabelle?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: How do you know me? Who are you?

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Isabelle...? The Wolf GROWLS, cutting her off, and turns back to Isabelle. It moves closer. Isabelle looks into its eyes. They suddenly seem very big and deep, almost hypnotizing. She seems to fall into them...

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: What big eyes you have...

Speaker: the wolf
Dialogue: The better to see you with, my dear.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Are you going to kill us?

Speaker: the wolf
Dialogue: Kill you? Why would I kill you?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Then what do you want?

Speaker: the wolf
Dialogue: I want you, Isabelle. Isabelle gapes, dumbstruck and dismayed.

Speaker: the wolf
Dialogue: We are the same, you and I. We are both wild things. You show one face to the world, but there is another face that you hide. A fire burning inside you, waiting to be released. The Wolf sniffs her, starting at her feet and working its way up. It SNARLS with satisfaction, savoring her scent.

Speaker: the wolf
Dialogue: Yes. I can smell it on you even now. Suddenly, the Wolf jumps onto its hind legs, puts its forepaws on the wall on either side of Isabelle, its muzzle only inches from her face. She recoils.

Speaker: the wolf
Dialogue: Leave with me tonight. Run with me. The only shackles binding you are of your own making. Slip them and I can show you the world and every pleasure in it. Isabelle hesitates, then finds the strength to speak:

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I don't know who you are, but we are not the same. I would rather die than go with you.

Speaker: the wolf
Dialogue: What about your fat friend here? Do you think she would rather die?  Come away with me. Or I will kill her. And I will keep killing until you agree to leave with me. Suddenly, the sound of MEN SHOUTING. The Wolf leans in, SNARLING. Isabelle turns away from its foul breath.

Speaker: the wolf
Dialogue: Choose now. Quickly. Isabelle trembles. She looks down at Roxanne's terrified face, torn. Isabelle closes her eyes. She can't do it.

Speaker: the wolf
Dialogue: Your silence has doomed them all. Just then, Solomon and two Soldiers turn the corner. The Wolf leaps atop the wall and growls down at Isabelle:

Speaker: the wolf
Dialogue: Come the next full moon, their blood will be on your hands. Then it jumps over the wall. Solomon scrabbles up after it, but the Wolf is already too far away. It looks back at him. A silent challenge passes between them. And then the Wolf is gone.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: We are safe here. God protects his own house and those within it. Isabelle finds Prudence.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Is Peter here?

Speaker: prudence
Dialogue: Peter? I don't think so.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: What about Claude? Or my parents?

Speaker: prudence
Dialogue: I haven't seen any of them.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Would you look for them? Please? Prudence nods and rushes off. Roxanne slumps in a corner, a dazed look on her face. A beat.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: You talked to it.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: It talked to us. A chill runs down Roxanne's spine. A long beat.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: No. It only growled.  You heard it talk to you? Isabelle doesn't know what to say. She glances around to see if anyone has overheard. Then:

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Do not speak of this to anyone. Roxanne nods, but eyes Isabelle warily. Isabelle turns away, afraid and confused.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Mother! Father!

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Is she dead?

Speaker: cesaire
Dialogue: No, thank God.

Speaker: father auguste
Dialogue: This man is alive!

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Are you bitten? Shivering, the Soldier nods. The Captain closes his eyes. Solomon stands and turns to Father Auguste.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Step back. Confused, Father Auguste does as he's told. Then, before anyone can react, Solomon draws his sword and plunges it into the Soldier's heart. Everyone startles.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: The werewolf's bite is the same as death to a man. Stunned silence. Solomon turns to the Villagers.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: The dark days have returned to your village. Your homes are no longer safe. The Wolf will return. Again and again. And it will not stop until it has sucked the marrow from all your bones. Unless you stop it.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: It appears my expertise is not as appreciated as I was led to believe. He turns to leave. Suddenly, Attewater steps forward.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: Wait! Attewater drops to one knee. Solomon stops and gives him an appraising look. Then Solomon turns to the Villagers. After a moment, the Reeve drops to his knee. One by one, the Villagers kneel to Solomon. Henri and Father Auguste are among the last, but they reluctantly kneel as well.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: We will do what must be done. A beat. Then Solomon offers his hand. Attewater kisses Solomon's ring. Henri and Roxanne exchange uneasy looks.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: I was up all night worrying about you. Thank God you're safe. But something about her expression gives him pause. She looks up at him, struggling with what she has to say.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Peter... My mother's hurt. I can't leave. Not now.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: I thought you didn't want to wait.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I don't have any choice. It's not just my mother. Something else happened last night.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I meant everything I said. This isn't what I wanted.

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: Of course not. You'd better go home and see to your mother. She gives him a sad nod, then turns to go. She pauses at the door, but he doesn't look at her. She leaves.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Silver. This is our most potent weapon. One blow will kill it.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: If it's that powerful, how can we possibly hope to stop it?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: We must find it in its human form. Who among you do you suspect? Attewater and Father Auguste trade uncomfortable looks. Neither of them wants to speak up first.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: It has not survived this long by being obvious. The signs will be subtle. Insomnia. Restlessness. Strange behavior. Strange smells.  Well, none of them smell good, but we must start somewhere.

Speaker: father auguste
Dialogue: What about the hair Madame Ordeville found on Lucie's body? It was dark. The person we are looking for must have dark hair.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Perhaps. Unless it planted the hair to make us think that.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: Yes, it's trying to trick us again. This has been happening for forty years. It must be an old man by now. The hair should have been gray.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Not necessarily. It may be the child or grandchild of the werewolf that first struck here.

Speaker: father auguste
Dialogue: The curse is hereditary?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: It is. But it effects men and women differently. A man can inherit the curse. Or he can be turned simply by being bitten. Solomon turns toward the fire and stares into it.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: But women are immune to the werewolf's bite. In order for a woman to be turned, she must inherit the curse. But even then it will lie dormant unless she eats human flesh. Only then will the bite of a male werewolf change her. Only then can she become a werewolf and capable of passing the curse on to her own children.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: But it could be a woman.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Of course. It could be any one of you. Attewater and Father Auguste exchange a wary look.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Has Claude come home?

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: No. Nobody has seen him.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: He's run away before. He'll be all right. Roxanne nods, unconvinced. Prudence joins them. They all exchange a sad look.

Speaker: prudence
Dialogue: Well. I suppose this is all of us. The three of them turn and start toward the woods...

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: It talked to you. And you understood it?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: As clearly as I do you now. Grandmother fixes her with a serious look. A beat.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Word of this cannot be allowed to spread. Do you understand me?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Roxanne will never speak of it. She won't even talk to me about it. A long beat. Isabelle is working up her nerve. Then:

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I have to do what it wants.  I have communed with an unholy beast. What does that make me if not cursed?

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: I don't know. But I won't allow you to go with this devil and live as its concubine.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: But if it comes back for me and I don't go with it, then it will kill again. If I have the power to save even one life, aren't I compelled to do so?

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: This is why it chose you. You're a good girl with a gentle heart. It's using that against you.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: But how could it? Unless it really does know me? Isabelle and Grandmother exchange an anxious look...

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: I spoke with your father. I broke off our engagement.  I saw you with Peter. Don't worry, I didn't tell anyone. Isabelle can't hide her shock. She shifts anxiously.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: What about my family's debt?

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: I have no interest in ruining your family. I will have you out of love or not at all. Isabelle is dumbfounded. Henri turns and walks away...

Speaker: prudence
Dialogue: They've caught the werewolf!

Speaker: prudence
Dialogue: He's been hiding in a hayloft. They caught him trying to steal food.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: But who is it? An angry crowd has gathered. Solomon's Soldiers are all that's stopping it from turning into a lynch mob. Isabelle finds Roxanne in tears, trying to force her way through the crowd.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: What's wrong? What's happening? Roxanne doesn't answer, just plunges into the crowd. Isabelle goes in after her. Cesaire tries to stop her.

Speaker: cesaire
Dialogue: Isabelle! Get away from there! She follows Roxanne to the front of the crowd, just as two Soldiers haul a figure out of a barn -- it's Claude.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Claude!!

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: It's not him! It can't be!

Speaker: lucrece
Dialogue: If he's not the werewolf, then why was he hiding? What's he afraid of? The Soldiers carry Claude off and Roxanne stumbles after them. Isabelle tries to follow, but Cesaire stops her. She can only watch helplessly as Claude is dragged away.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: The good of the people is the chief law.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: You read Latin.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: And write. I was studying to be a nun when I met my husband.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: He must have been some man.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: He was a priest. She grins. Is she being serious? Attewater bristles.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: You know the boy is innocent. He's being tried because he's different. Because Father Solomon knows he can turn us against him.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: Father Solomon is here to protect us.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: A wolf hunting sheep picks off the weakest ones first.  This is just the beginning. She enters the manor hall. Attewater watches her go.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: You say you saw the accused perform magic?

Speaker: lucrece
Dialogue: In broad daylight with my own eyes. Everyone here has seen it.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: So it was common knowledge that the accused was a conjurer?

Speaker: lucrece
Dialogue: Yes, Your Eminence. I saw it for the Devil's work, but they laughed at me and paid him money. Isabelle and Grandmother exchange a concerned look. Through a SERIES OF CUTS, more witnesses are questioned:

Speaker: father auguste
Dialogue: shifts uncomfortably as Solomon interrogates him...

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Are you aware that it is the custom of witches and devil worshippers to hold their black sabbaths in cemeteries?

Speaker: father auguste
Dialogue: Yes, Your Eminence.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: And do you know of their practice of dancing with invisible devils during these rituals?

Speaker: father auguste
Dialogue: I have heard it said so, yes.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Is there one here today who you have seen dancing in your cemetery?

Speaker: father auguste
Dialogue: Yes. But I don't believe he meant anything by it. It was in jest.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: So you consider the black mass to be a jest? There are suspicious WHISPERS among the Villagers. Father Auguste eyes them nervously. A beat.

Speaker: father auguste
Dialogue: No, of course not.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Then point him out. Father Auguste reluctantly points to Claude.

Speaker: marguerite
Dialogue: Roxanne weeps as her mother testifies against Claude.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: What is your relationship to the accused?

Speaker: marguerite
Dialogue: I am his mother.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: And where is his father?

Speaker: marguerite
Dialogue: I don't know, sir.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Well, what is his name? She pauses. The crowd eyes her, disapproving. A beat.

Speaker: marguerite
Dialogue: I never learned his name, sir.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: You say a man whose name you cannot recall is the father of your child? What can you tell us about him?

Speaker: marguerite
Dialogue: Not much, sir. She lowers her eyes, ashamed. Solomon considers her.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Almost as if it were a dream?  Certain devils called incubi can collect human semen and then transfer it to women as they sleep. A woman who unwittingly conceives in this manner would not be a whore. She would be blameless in the eyes of God.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: You remember almost nothing of the man who impregnated you. Is it not possible that there was no man? That the accused is not the product of your own sin, but the foul offspring of a werewolf whose semen was placed in you by an incubus while you slept?

Speaker: marguerite
Dialogue: Yes! Yes, I remember now! He came to me in my sleep! It wasn't my fault! God save me, it wasn't my fault! Roxanne buries her face in her hands.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: We have proven here today that behind this veil of feigned idiocy is the fiend that has plagued your village. However, in order for the sentence of death to be carried out, the Church requires either a confession or the testimony of a witness who has seen the accused in his transformed state. Since the accused has refused to confess, this court calls upon its final witness. Isabelle Ordeville. Isabelle is stunned. All eyes turn toward her.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: On the night of the last full moon, you were attacked by the Wolf. You looked it in the eye. And the one thing a werewolf can never change is its eyes.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Look into his eyes, my child. Do you see the beast in them? Isabelle gives Claude a pitying look. Solomon watches, expectant. Then:

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: It isn't him. It can't be. He was with us when the Wolf attacked. Solomon is taken aback. Surprised MURMURS in the room.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Is this true? Is there another here who can speak to this?

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: I can! It's true! I saw him!

Speaker: lucrece
Dialogue: She's his sister! She'll say anything! The suspicious Villagers agree. Roxanne gives Isabelle a desperate look. Then Isabelle spots the Carpenter.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: He was there! He carried Claude away! He saved his life! Suddenly, all eyes are on the Carpenter. He shrinks back. He glances at his WIFE. She stares at him. Hard.

Speaker: carpenter
Dialogue: She is mistaken. I did no such thing. Isabelle is shocked. She looks to the other Villagers, but no one will speak up. Solomon frowns.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Very well. Since no one here can bear witness, we must extort a confession. This court shall reconvene tomorrow at dawn. Solomon leaves. Claude is dragged out of the room by Soldiers. Isabelle gives Grandmother a helpless look.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Why wouldn't Father Solomon listen to me? Doesn't he care that Claude isn't guilty?

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: He'd rather let an innocent boy die than risk letting the Wolf go free.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: But the Wolf is free. And the moon will be full in two days. The full weight of this hits home. Grandmother leans close, lowers her voice.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: We both know it will be coming for you. You must leave here tomorrow and never return. A long beat. Isabelle reluctantly shakes her head.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I cannot leave.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: You have no choice. The alternative is unthinkable.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: What is unthinkable is that I should be responsible for the deaths of everyone that I love. I'd rather spend a lifetime of misery than let that happen.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: The Wolf's sins are on its own twice-damned soul, not yours.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: But what if it was you it wanted? Would you go with it to save me? Or would you leave me to die? Grandmother doesn't have a fast answer for that. Suddenly, a HIDEOUS, INARTICULATE SCREAM echoes in the night. Isabelle and Grandmother exchange a grave look.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Father Solomon. Extorting his confession. Claude's screams sending chills down their spines.

Speaker: cesaire
Dialogue: You should have condemned him today. At least it would have been quick. Cesaire turns and goes back inside. Isabelle and Grandmother continue to listen.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: How can you just sit there and listen to this? Marguerite ignores her. Furious, Roxanne stands up and grabs Marguerite's coin purse.

Speaker: marguerite
Dialogue: Where are you going with that? Roxanne doesn't answer, just pulls on her cloak. Marguerite grabs her, but Roxanne turns and shoves her to the ground. Marguerite starts to get up, but Roxanne snatches a knife from off the table and points it at her.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Don't you touch me again. Ever. Roxanne angrily throws the knife aside and leaves.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Enough of this. Let's eat. He gestures to the Scribe, who hands Attewater a document.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: What is this?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: A statement declaring that you heard the boy confess. All it requires is your signature. Or your mark, if you cannot write.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: But he has not confessed. How could he have? Solomon studies Attewater. A beat. Solomon shrugs.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Very well. Listen more carefully this time. He gestures for the Soldiers to throw more wood on the fire. The FLAMES leap higher. Attewater goes pale. All he hears are screams. Solomon stands next to the bull. The flames gleam off the brass, casting him in hellfire.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Listen to how he sings of his love of Satan. How he despairs that he will never again copulate with the dead or sink his teeth into the flesh of pregnant women and eat their unborn children. Attewater gives Solomon a horrified look, suddenly realizing. Father Solomon is insane.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: Stop this.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: No. You stop it.  We both know he is guilty. But I cannot legally execute him without a witness or a confession. Sign this and we have a confession. Attewater glares at Solomon, then angrily signs the document. Solomon gestures to his Soldiers, who open the bull and pull Claude out. Attewater has to look away.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: This is the business of werewolf hunting and you had best develop a stomach for it. Because where there is one werewolf, there are two. And where there are two, there are more.

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: A girl to see you.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Well, I've yet to come across a girl I wouldn't at least look at. The Captain ushers Roxanne inside. She meekly steps forward. A beat.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I assume you came here with a purpose. She hurriedly empties Marguerite's purse on the table in front of Solomon. A mere handful of coins.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: I would like to bargain for the release of my brother.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Your brother has just confessed.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: What? That's not possible!

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: It has been witnessed and notarized. He will hang in the morning.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: I have more than money to offer you. She raises a trembling hand and starts to open her bodice, but Solomon interrupts.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: What do you think you are doing?  Do you have any idea who I am? I am the Witchfinder General. I have fought in the Holy Land. I have waded hip deep in blood and resisted all the temptations of the infidels. And you seek to stay the hand of justice with such a tawdry bribe? Leave here, girl, before I have you whipped. Solomon gestures for the Soldiers and they forcibly drag her away. Roxanne struggles against them.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Wait! I have something else! I know the name of a witch! Solomon looks up sharply. The Soldiers stop. Solomon crosses the room and stands glaring down at Roxanne. She cringes. This is the hardest decision of her life...

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Spare my brother and I will tell you her name.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: How are you acquainted with the accused?

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: We were friends.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: And how long did this friendship last?

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: All my life.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: And in this time, have you ever known the accused to converse with devils?

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Yes, Your Eminence. On the night of the last full moon, she talked to the werewolf. And later she told me that it also talked to her. Isabelle gives Grandmother a frightened look. Cesaire clenches his fist. Solomon turns to Isabelle.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: What of this? Do you deny having conversed with a werewolf? She looks to Roxanne, who trembles with emotion. Then:

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: No. I do not deny it. The crowd REACTS. Solomon quiets them with a look.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Describe this encounter.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: It spoke, just as a man speaks.

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: And what was the nature of your conversation with it? Isabelle hesitates. Grandmother holds her breath.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: It told me... It promised to leave here and never return. But only if I leave with it. Roxanne gives her a stunned look. A heavy silence falls over the room. Even Solomon is surprised. Then:

Speaker: reeve
Dialogue: But who is it? Make her tell us who the werewolf is!

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I don't know! I swear I don't know!

Speaker: merchant
Dialogue: It doesn't matter who it is anymore. It wants her, not us. Let's just give it what it wants. A long, tense beat. Heavy silence. Nobody speaks.

Speaker: father auguste
Dialogue: We should not allow ourselves to even consider this.

Speaker: reeve
Dialogue: I think we already are.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: What's the matter with you? You know her. You all know her.

Speaker: reeve
Dialogue: Do we? Did we know she could talk to werewolves?

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: She could have run away. She could saved herself, but she stayed here because she cares more about you than she does herself.

Speaker: merchant
Dialogue: If she stayed, she did so because she is in league with it. Let this be her punishment. The crowd loudly AGREES. Solomon considers. Grandmother gives Attewater a dark look. Then:

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: Very well. Isabelle Ordeville, in light of your willing confession, it is the decision of this court that on the night of the next full moon, you be left to the mercy of the werewolf. Cesaire silently buries his face in his hands.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: No! Henri bursts to his feet, turning heads. Isabelle is led away. Roxanne can only watch, helpless and ashamed.

Speaker: lucrece
Dialogue: The first victim was her sister. The second was her fiance's father. Then Rosemaria, who everyone knows she hated. And don't forget her mother, with half her face missing. All this death around one girl... Prudence has heard enough. She turns away.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: I'm here for my brother. He gestures. Roxanne turns... and sees Claude's body dangling from a makeshift gallows. He's been hanged.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: I'm not going to let these worthless shits sacrifice you to save themselves. We have to find the real werewolf before tomorrow night.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: That's impossible. Even Father Solomon doesn't have the first clue.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Father Solomon doesn't know the things that I know.  I am the oldest person in this village who was here when the Wolf first came. I remember the old days. And what is happening now is much worse.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: What was it like in the old days?

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: The Wolf never used to attack in the open like it did at the festival. It's a coward at heart. It would kill whole families in their homes, but it always stayed in the shadows. It never would have shown itself in the old days.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: It's grown bold.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Or perhaps it made a mistake.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: But who would want to kill Lucie?

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Your parents said that the Wolf broke into the house and took Lucie. We both know that's not true. What really happened? Isabelle hesitates, reluctant.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: My mother made me swear I would never speak of it.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Why would you think such a thing?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: She was in love with Henri.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: She took her own life over a boy?

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: What other explanation is there? Grandmother thinks. The pieces are fitting together...

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Hello, Henri.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: You spoke up very loudly in Isabelle's defense today. That was very brave.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: I just said what I felt.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: You're under no obligation to stand in her defense. You broke off your engagement to her.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: I never stopped caring about her. I would do anything for Isabelle.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: As her sister would have done anything for you.  Lucie was in love with you. But you knew that, didn't you?

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: I had no control over the way she felt.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: She kept it secret from almost everyone. Even Isabelle didn't know. Did you tell anyone?

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: Never.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Not even your father?

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: I didn't have to tell him.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: So he knew your secrets, did he? Henri picks up a hammer and goes back to work. Angrily nailing a shoe to the horse's foot. BANG! BANG! BANG!

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: You were the only one who could have lured Lucie out on the Wolf's night. And none of the men who went hunting for the Wolf remember seeing you after the sun set on the night your father died. Henri faces her, clutching the hammer...

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: Why are you doing this?

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Because I want you to confess. You killed Lucie. And your father. And God only knows how many others. And if you won't admit it, then I will tell Father Solomon and we will lock you up until the moon rises tomorrow night and you can no longer hide your guilt. As she says this, a slow look of dawning realization comes over him. Realization and horror.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: It's you. Henri steps closer to her, menacing. Grandmother steps back and finds herself bumping against the closed door.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: My God, it's you. You're the Wolf. I can smell it on you now.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Smell what? What are you talking about?

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: The night my father died. I saw the Wolf pass by, dragging him by the neck. I was so terrified I couldn't move or make a sound. I remember every detail of that moment. The way the moonlight gleamed off the Wolf's coat. The soundless way it moved. I even remember the way it smelled. A thick, greasy, musky stink.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: You accuse me and I'll bring you down with me. All they can do is take my life. You have more to lose.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: But who do you think they'll believe? I'm the blacksmith.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Then I'll have to prove it.

Speaker: henri
Dialogue: Unless you can, you'd best keep your mouth shut. Another beat. A stand-off. Grandmother's hand finds the door handle. She turns it, stumbling outside --

Speaker: cesaire
Dialogue: Are you ready for me to take you home? She looks back. Henri stands in the doorway, still holding the hammer. She eyes him, measuring, suddenly hesitant. Cesaire gives them both an uncertain look.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Stop the cart. Cesaire pulls the reins. Grandmother calls out:

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Prudence, come with me. I have some blankets I want you to mend for Father Auguste. Prudence sighs and climbs up into the cart.

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: You take these blankets to Father Auguste the moment you're finished. Understand?

Speaker: prudence
Dialogue: All right. Cesaire helps Grandmother out of the cart.

Speaker: cesaire
Dialogue: Will you want a ride into town tomorrow? To say goodbye to her?

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Yes. First thing in the morning. He nods shakily and leaves. She closes the door behind him and lets the faade of calm fall from her face. She puts a trembling hand to her mouth, mind racing...

Speaker: herald
Dialogue: Full moon! Full moon! Full moon!

Speaker: grandmother
Dialogue: Show yourself! Coward! Another beat. The veil settles and is still. Then: A FIGURE lunges out of the veil with its arms reaching out at us. It grabs Grandmother's throat in one hand and wrestles the cane from her grip with the other. She struggles, but she's far too weak for her attacker. The Figure whips out a knife. Grandmother sees it, but can do nothing. The knife flashes. Fat drops of blood splash on the floor. Then the Figure drops Grandmother and she crumples, lifeless. A pool of blood slowly spreads out from underneath her. The Figure steps over the widening pool and picks up the letter Grandmother was writing. He quickly scans it and angrily tosses it in the fire... Then he hears something. FOOTSTEPS, crunching through the snow. He hurries to the window and peers out... It's Roxanne and Prudence. Roxanne looks like hell, but here for lessons as usual. The Figure ducks out of sight. A moment later, they're KNOCKING on the door. Their feet are visible under the crack. The Figure sidles alongside the door, BREATHING heavily. Another KNOCK. On the floor inside, the pool of blood is expanding toward the door... The Figure sees it. He puts a hand on the hilt of his knife... then whispers to the girls through the door, disguising his voice with a dry, old woman's rasp:

Speaker: the figure
Dialogue: Go away. Outside, Roxanne and Prudence exchange a curious look.

Speaker: prudence
Dialogue: Are you all right?

Speaker: the figure
Dialogue: I'm sick. You can't come in.

Speaker: prudence
Dialogue: You sound awful. Would you like us to make you something?

Speaker: the figure
Dialogue: No. You mustn't come in. Go home, now. I want to sleep.

Speaker: roxanne
Dialogue: Are you sure you don't want us to bring you something?

Speaker: the figure
Dialogue: No, my dear. Come back tomorrow. The blood is seconds away from hitting her feet. The Figure stands poised to throw open the door... but at the last instant, Roxanne turns and walks away. She doesn't see the blood pour outside under the door behind her.

Speaker: father auguste
Dialogue: I've come to hear your final confession. Isabelle nods shakily and sits up. He enters.

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: Has there been any word from my grandmother?

Speaker: father auguste
Dialogue: None that I have heard. Why? Isabelle doesn't answer. She turns away, troubled...

Speaker: servant boy
Dialogue: She's still in the dungeon. They're going to move her at sunset. Peter tosses the Boy a coin. The Boy runs off. Peter looks at the stone house, his eyes hard and determined...

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: We've hanged the werewolf. Why not let the girl go free?

Speaker: solomon
Dialogue: I told you, Bailiff. Where there is one werewolf, there are more. And the girl is the bait for our trap. Father Solomon strides off. Attewater watches him go...

Speaker: peter
Dialogue: I need your help. Off Henri's look...

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: Where is your mother?

Speaker: cesaire
Dialogue: I don't know. I went to pick her up this morning and she was gone.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: Stop pouring that swill down your gullet listen to me! Cesaire emerges from his drunken fog and shoots him a dangerous look, but Attewater doesn't shy from it.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: She was trying to find the werewolf. If she figured out who it is, I need to know now. Suddenly, the door bursts open and the Captain enters, flanked by Soldiers. They drag Cesaire to his feet.

Speaker: attewater
Dialogue: Wait! What has he done?

Speaker: captain
Dialogue: It's just a precaution. Father Solomon doesn't want the girl's family interfering. Suddenly, Cesaire pulls a club out of his boot and hits the Captain across the back, knocking him to his knees. Cesaire hits him again, then he's wrestled to the ground. The Captain kicks Cesaire in the face and knocks him out. The Soldiers drag him away. Attewater watches them go...

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: What have you done to him?! Then: Isabelle's cell is opened. The Captain is holding iron manacles. Isabelle looks at them, horrified. The Soldiers clap her in irons. This is really happening...

Speaker: isabelle
Dialogue: I love you so much. Tell Mama and Grandmother that I love them.

Speaker: cesaire
